titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the New York City WPA historical survey of Indigenous People of Brooklyn 1977.121
titlestmt.author: Nicholas Pavlik
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described as part of the project, "Uncovering the Secrets of Brooklyn's 19th Century Past: Creation to Consolidation," funded by the Council on Library and Information Resources, with additional support from The Gladys Krieble Delmas Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2021-08-25 13:41:51 +0000.

did.unittitle: New York City WPA historical survey of Indigenous People of Brooklyn

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: United States. Works Projects Administration (New York, N.Y.)

did.abstract: This collection includes drafted sections of "The Indians of Brooklyn in the Days of the Dutch," edited by William Christie MacLeod, which have been organized by subject. It also includes research notes, annotated maps, notes on the orthography of Native American words and names, and typescript copies of 17th century deeds and proclamations. Please note: A bound copy of "The Indians of Brooklyn in the Days of the Dutch" is available in our regular non-circulating library collection; see our library catalog for more information.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The New York City Work Projects Administration (WPA) Historical Records Survey was one of the many cultural projects initiated as part of the WPA's federal relief programs from 1935 to 1943. This collection represents the efforts of the Historical Records Survey to collect, transcribe and explain records pertaining to the Native American communities of 17th century Brooklyn.

Archaeological evidence testifies that Native Americans have been living in the region now comprising the five boroughs of New York City for at least 11,500 years. Native Americans living along the Atlantic seaboard between the Delaware and Hudson valleys refer to themselves as Lenape (people), though the Europeans arriving in the 16th and 17th century called them Delawares. Native Americans of the region are believed to have spoken a variant of Lenape/Delaware dialect known as Munsee. Documented Munsee communities who lived in the area that would eventually become known as Brooklyn included the Marechkawick (sandy place) near present-day Borough Hall, Nayack (point of land), Wichquawanck (sandy bank) at present-day Fort Hamilton, Techkonis (translation unknown) in present-day Gravesend, and Canarsie (grassy place) in present-day Flatlands.

list.head: Sources:
list.item: Grumet, Robert S. "American Indians," in The Encyclopedia of New York City, ed. Kenneth T. Jackson (New Haven, Conn.: Yale University Press; New York: New York Historical Society, c1995), 25-28.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); New York City WPA historical survey on American Indians of Brooklyn, 1977.121, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Historical Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection includes drafted sections of "The Indians of Brooklyn in the Days of the Dutch," edited by William Christie MacLeod, as well as research notes, annotated maps, notes on the orthography of Native American words and names, and typescript copies of 17th century deeds and proclamations.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Deposited by the New York City WPA, 1941.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The materials in this collection have been processed to the folder level. Materials are separated by type and subject.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Materials were rehoused, and folder level description was added in 2020. The collection was renamed from the New York City WPA historical survey of American Indians of Brooklyn to New York City WPA historical survey of Indeigenous Peoples of Brooklyn to reflect current terminology.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright status of materials in this collection is unknown, copyright may rest with WPA or original artists. Please consult library staff for more information.

Drafts – Villages: Marechkawick, Wickquawonck and Techkonis
